Award.AwardTitle: Testing the State and Trait Accuracy Model: Links between Accuracy of Judging Affect and Accuracy of Judging Traits

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Decision making is a process that is an essential, but challenging, aspect of people's personal and professional lives. Important decisions about another person are often based on first impressions. Impressions can include the emotional state a person is feeling at that moment, or "affect", and how that person generally thinks and acts: his or her personality traits. Making accurate judgments has vital effects on the actions people take. Judging that a person's affect is positive or negative allows people to decide whether approach or avoidance is best at that moment. Accurately judging traits is useful for the "who" and "how" of social living. People determine whom to approach with what goal in mind, and they anticipate how such interactions might unfold. Making good decisions in a variety of contexts is likely to lead to quality relationships or collaborations and avoidance of negative ones. This, in turn, may increase well-being, employee satisfaction, and productivity. Although accurately judging both affect and stable traits is crucial to making high quality decisions, researchers have developed models of these two kinds of judgments independent of each other. The current project provides an innovative merging of these areas of research, producing a model of how accuracy across these judgment areas may be related. The investigators will test the newly developed State and Trait Accuracy Model in four experiments. In addition, the project provides research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, and engagement in science for students in primary schools.

This project tests two hypotheses about the relationship and causal direction of people's accuracy in judging affect and judging traits. The State and Trait Accuracy Model predicts a positive relationship between such judgments, and further predicts that judgments of affect precede accurate judgments of personality traits. To test hypotheses about the accuracy of judging strangers, it is essential to have stimuli that display genuine emotions and responses, rather than staged or artificial affective displays. Thus, researchers from the three universities involved in this project have developed a validated database of stimuli consisting of videotapes of individuals whose personality traits and emotional state have been assessed. In the current project, experiments will use segments of these videotapes as stimuli for observers to make affect and trait judgments. Four experiments involve manipulating observers' judgmental focus and manipulating the validity of affect and trait information, either by mislabeling or by natural incongruences. Undergraduate and graduate students will be involved as researchers and participants in the project, providing research training opportunities. Children in local primary schools will benefit by exposure to presentations and research design experiences provided in their schools. Another benefit of this project is that the infrastructure for research is enhanced via this collaboration of researchers at three North American universities. In addition, society can benefit from an increased understanding of how affective states and personality traits can be judged more accurately--something useful to people in daily life as well as to professionals. For instance, the U.S. economy may benefit from employers being better able to determine the fit between applicants and jobs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Decision making is an essential, but challenging, aspect of life. Important decisions about others are partly based on first impressions of emotional states and personality traits (how people generally think, feel, and behave). Making good decisions based on accurate judgments is likely to lead to higher quality relationships or collaborations, which could increase general well-being and employee satisfaction and productivity. This project tested two main hypotheses of a new model of accurate judgments - the State and Trait Accuracy Model (STAM): there is a positive relationship between accuracy of judgments of emotions and traits, and accurate judgments of emotions will lead to more accurate judgments of traits. Two types of accuracy were assessed: distinctive accuracy (how well people judge how others are different from the average person) and normative accuracy (similarity between judgments of individuals and what the average person is like).

Intellectual Merit

The first study in this project provided evidence that judgments of emotions and traits are positively related for both distinctive and normative accuracy. Judges who achieved higher levels of accuracy for traits also achieved higher levels of accuracy for emotions. When examining specific traits and positive and negative affect (PA and NA) separately, distinctive accuracy for extraversion was positively related to distinctive accuracy for PA and NA, distinctive accuracy for conscientiousness and PA were positively related, and distinctive accuracy for agreeableness and NA were negatively related. Additionally, normative accuracy for extraversion, neuroticism, and conscientiousness were positively related to normative accuracy for PA.

The next three studies tested the causal link between accuracy of judging emotions and traits. The first study examined the effects of having valid information, invalid information, or no information about one domain (emotions or traits) on distinctive accuracy for the other domain. For ratings of traits, distinctive accuracy was about the same for judges with valid information and no information, but was lower with invalid information. For ratings of emotions, distinctive accuracy did not differ across conditions. Therefore, invalid information about affect decreased judges' ability to make accurate judgments about traits.

A second study examined how high vs. low congruence between self-reported emotions of targets (the people being judged) and emotions that were coded by objective observers affected accuracy. It was predicted that distinctive accuracy for traits and emotions would be higher for judgments of targets with higher emotion congruence. For ratings of emotion, this is what was found. However, for ratings of traits, distinctive accuracy was higher for judgments of targets with low congruence. One explanation for this finding is that targets with high congruence were expressing more negative emotions, which led judges to pay less attention to them and therefore have lower distinctive accuracy.

The final study examined how focusing on a certain domain (emotions, traits, or physical appearance) while watching videos of others affected the accuracy of judgments of emotions and traits. It was predicted that distinctive accuracy for traits would be highest when judges focused on emotion, followed by focusing on traits, followed by focusing on physical appearance. The prediction was not supported. Instead, distinctive accuracy for judgments of traits was not influenced by the domain on which judges were instructed to focus, but was high across all domains. 

Broader Impacts

Preliminary results have been presented at three annual meetings of the Society for Personality and Social Psychology, the model and a test of the model using existing data was described in a published journal article, and a description of the model and basic results have been included in two handbook chapters. The results from all four studies will be presented in a single peer-reviewed journal article. Materials, data, and analyses are available on the Open Science Framework at https://osf.io/rezzy/. An introduction to psychology, descriptions of STAM, and preliminary results were presented to students in seven schools (including four high schools, one middle school, and one elementary school). As a result of these presentations, the PI mentored two research projects of middle school students that were presented at the school’s science fair. This allowed young students who would not normally be exposed to this type of information to learn about psychological research and some findings from this project.

 

Training was provided to four graduate research assistants, one post-doctoral researcher, and several undergraduate students who helped organize materials and data collection, collected and analyzed data, and presented findings. This project strengthened cross-university collaborations and provides an example of how research on accuracy of emotion judgments and trait judgments can be combined to enhance understanding of these processes. The findings will be presented to large lay audiences to help people understand the process of making accurate judgments and how this could increase the quality of their decisions about others.
